Also salary is lower than other HMS institutions with a large amount of post docs not even making the NIH minimum, the hospital has promised to correct that in 6 months but it’s been fought for by the postdoc association for the last few years. Further they run a postdoc program where they take in international MDs every year (50+) and do not pay them nor give them any benefits. Seems unethical and clearly doesn’t promote diversity as postdocs need full financial support from families to afford to live in Boston with no paycheck dispute having a medical degree.

review_title: Welcome to the Beth Israel Caste System
pros: You'll find nice co-workers at BI. Most staff can now work remotely.
cons:
Low salary where support staff is not well compensated. "Other duties as assigned" is the motto and don't expect your paycheck to reflect the extra work. And don't make any errors. You are there to make the faculty's life flow without interruption and anything you do not foresee is your fault, whether it is your responsibility or not. If you are an admin., you are the lowest person in the caste system and subject to constant scrutiny.

BI claims they have no money, but spared no expense rebranding for the Lahey merger and compensates doctors and faculty well. 

Poor communication across all channels.

Operations are a mystery that you must unravel.

IS is a nightmare.

pros: The people on 'the ground' are very committed to what they do, to supporting one another and providing good patient care.  There is a great working and supportive culture amongst the people who directly and indirectly provide care to patients.  I think BI takes pride in being the underdog in the Boston community.  We are not the overgrown and overcompensated 'Partners' but we are more 'boutique' and get to provide a more personal level of care.
cons: The upper management and Chiefs of services are very involved in politics and cloaking whatever it is they are up to.  This was a glaring, majority issue brought to light in a recent hospital survey.  There used to exist a 'transparent culture' at BI which has now gone to the other extreme.   Our institution and culture is suffering because of it.  We train people up for a few years and then they leave for better salaries and work-life balances at other institutions.  This is not good for morale and is also not cost effective for the hospital yet it continues to be downplayed and largely Ignored by upper management.

review_title: Bad institute for basic research - great PI
pros:
1. 5 Stars for my PI and Lab. They have been terrific. Only reason I stayed for this long.
2. Postdoctoral association working hard to help postdocs.
cons:
1. No automatic annual increase in pay. This means you could get a fixed amount for the period of your employment. If your PI has funds to give you a raise, processing the paperwork could take 5+ months due to slow management.
2. Not providing minimum salary recommended by NIH when joining based on experience. They provide only PY0 pay even if you have more experience when you join. This means not only don't you get raises but you are stuck on pay which is outdated if you stay more than 1 year.
Important to negotiate when joining which is unusual for postdoc positions elsewhere in the neighboring institutes which have minimum salaries that are much better.
3. Poor facilities for basic research. Some examples:
- IT will not allow you to install software for your research. Even software for instruments takes IT a long time to clear to get installed. IT support is specific for clinical work but if you are doing basic research it is inadequate. Using your computer to connect to their network is also a nightmare.
- Infrastructure for research is outdated. The clinical part of the hospital is fine but the labs for basic research are old. Temperatures in certain instrument rooms go very high in the summer, borderline damaging instruments.
- Core facilities are good but the institution provides very little support to them, making them understaffed/overworked.
- Instrument service plans by official vendors do not get approved, making instrument failures catastrophic and again slowing down research.
Overall, surprisingly poor infrastructure considering they are a Harvard Medical School affiliated hospital. 
4. Understaffed immigration office. If you are a postdoc and are on a visa you have to be on top of your immigration documents at all times, else you could be stuck. Fellow researchers had to leave the country for prolonged periods or permanently due to visa issues which could have been avoided.
5. No internal funding opportunities for postdocs e.g. no travel awards etc. If they are there, they are not well advertised in any way.
6. No clear pathway to progress up and get promoted even if you have exceptional performance in your annual review.
7. Health insurance and benefits provided are more expensive in comparison to neighboring institutes in the Longwood Medical area.

job_title: Help Desk Analyst in Boston, MA
pros: You learn a lot on how to troubleshoot with users and
cons: There is no encouragement to grow away from this position.

job_title: Medical Assistant Ll in Chestnut Hill, MA
pros: Great company, great co-workers, career development
cons: Vacation/ Sick time come from the same time bank

pros: the best place to work
cons: not the worst place to work

pros: The pros is flexible hours
cons: Nothing that I can think of.

pros: good environment, a well-prepared system for employee
cons: low salary, lack of regulation for researchers

pros: I have a flexible work schedule
cons: I work Long hour most days

review_title: Good company but overlooks poor management
pros: Great CEO. Have the chance to meet a few friendly coworkers. Plenty of educational trainings. Super large company with great HR department and policies.
cons: Poor management, lack of management. Managers should be put through trainings and evaluated more closely. Not enough praise for the employees that deserve it. You're expected to do so much but get no praise or positive feedback, only nonproductive criticism. Communication is horrible, there is no conflict resolution from the manager, only told to fix any problems yourselves. When you're working with childish coworkers who know the manager personally, it's always going to be your fault. I'm unsure of how a manager can get away with such nepotism without someone realizing. Managers take all the credit for the success of the department and reward only the people they knows or is of the same ethnic/cultural background. Pay is all over the board, some are getting paid super large amounts while others get scraps for doing the same job. The ones that get paid the most don't deserve it and do the least of course. Manager goes missing/out for cigarette breaks every 45 mins and takes their employee friends with her.

job_title: Director of Development in Boston, MA
pros: Dynamic leader in healthcare for Massachusetts with long history of serving diverse populations
cons: Working to gain greater visibility for its world-class research and patient-centered care

pros: World class teachers and educators
cons: World class teachers, educators, and co-trainees

pros: My coworkers are all pretty nice
cons: Treatment of nurses is very bad

job_title: Certified Surgical Technologist in Boston, MA
pros: Scheduling flexibility and supportive management.
cons: No employee parking for day shift

pros: Excellent patient-first vibe, transparent administration, and team atmosphere.
cons: Salaries are low due to saturated market

pros: Great environment, friendly staff. Highly recommend.
cons: Crowded campus, parking expensive for employees.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Great work environment. Staff is very friendly!
cons: overall a great experience working here.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Needham, MA
pros: Great place to be and work
cons: Fantastic place to be and work

job_title: Staff RN II in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: high medical standards, great team work.
cons: often staffing ratio issues as with most hospitals

review_title: A horrible place for academic research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: You get to have the Harvard Medical School title affixed to your name as an appointment.  This will help me get my next job.
cons:
As a hospital, I'm sure they are great. But they make researchers feel like 2nd class citizens.  Procurement is a horrible joke, since no P-cards are allowed, orders take up to a week to arrive via next-day shipping (the delay is at the purchasing department).  The benefits are lousy and postdocs pay the city maximum (Universities often give free benefits to postdocs, and BIDMC has the highest employee contributions in the area). Rather than give a fitness reimbursement, they offer their own lousy gym at $13 a week. No thanks.
No discounts for employees at their own cafeteria.  The technicians are overworked, as their policies do not allow overtime and make them take holidays they might otherwise would have worked (like MLK day).
No thought was given for configuration of research space. Their new building is laid out terribly, with core facilities separated by a 5 minute walk that includes the CAFETERIA!  The actual research space was designed with no thought to actual research, with bays lacking suitable gas/vacuum hookups and enough light.

job_title: Engineering Project Associate in Toronto, ON
pros: FYI, this does not cover the medical staff and their departments. The best aspects of working in the Facilities are their health benefits and the flexible schedule. We receive really good benefits which help if you go to the doctor often. The hours of work are flexible, which helps with personal life and activities. Working for an institution that improves people’s health is a great feeling, too.
cons: FYI, this does not cover the medical staff and their departments. The negative aspects of working in Facilities are the financial restrictions and the very slow promotion process. Since it’s a no profit organization, the salaries are lower then the other firms that do the same work in the city. Moving up the corporate ladder is very slow and sometimes impossible. The only way to get promoted sometimes is to get hired into a higher position as a new employee or wait for a senior employee to retire. There is also a lack of training to improve and sharpen employee’s skills.

review_title: Collaborative, supportive, creative, and dedicated to excellence - a great place to work!
pros:
BIDMC is indeed the Harvard medical school with a heart.  From the beginning, I found myself among colleagues looking to collaborate for the good of the institutions and its patients.  The physicians, nurses, and other professionals can go anywhere in the city, or world, to work, but the brightest often come and stay here because of the sense of community, passion, and commitment to patients.

There are always opportunities for growth, to be creative, to point out a problem and help to solve it.  Senior leadership is fairly accessible and take the time to understand what is happening on the front lines.  The Board leadership is also very dedicated.

The benefits are comparable to other institutions and my management team has been incredibly. helpful to me during difficult times when I needed to take time away from work for personal reasons.
cons: Faced paced environment can be stressful.  Does not offer a lot of tuition assistance ($1500 per calendar year).  In certain departments, people get ahead based on who they know, not their skills and contributions (IS in particular).

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Interesting research projects including both NIH-funded and industry-sponsored. Hands on experience that could be beneficial for people are looking for different things later on: graduate school, med school or move up the ladder in clinical research.
cons:
Hierarchy is the culture. Study coordinators seldom work with PIs directly, but with a Research Administrator (who is not directly involved in studies) who bridges the coordinators and PIs. This approach creates communication barriers, as well as prevents the opportunity to have a smooth workflow and healthy work relationship between study coordinators and PIs. 

Research coordinators function as research assistants. The department does not hire RAs citing reasons like "high turnover rate". For coordinators who are interested in gaining supervising experience, prioritizing RAs' work, this place can't offer that. 

Career advancement and growth opportunities are non-existence. Management has absolutely no plan or interest in advancing employees in their career. There is not a path for employees who are performing exceptionally and who want to move up. It is also not the culture to show appreciation and encouragement to employees, as it all comes down to "it's a coordinator's job".

review_title: Not a long term career for non clinical positions
pros:
Flexibility -at least in the department I work in the schedule is flexible, as long as you get your work done.

Depending on who you are can be a pro or a con, but basically, the pay scale rewards mediocrity, you can have the type of job where it's just a job go in at 9 leave at 5, you don't need to put in any effort because you're pretty much guaranteed a merit during review time.
cons:
Pay - one of the lowest in the Boston area.
Benefits - you would think working in a hospital you'd get better benefits, but the benefits here are expensive and mediocre.
Performance - as stated above, there is absolutely no incentive to go above and beyond in your job. Frustrating that you'll receive the same merit regardless of whether you put in the effort or not.
Management - pretty bad, they promote people into management positions that have no business being managers. Just because someone is good at their job doesn't mean they'll be able to effectively lead people.

review_title: Good company that has struggled to maintain its identity during merger.
pros:
Excellent clinical staff.
Potential for growth.
Interested in innovation.
cons: Unclear mandate from upper management. Besides "more" (more money, more patients), what is the goal of the medical center? What does "human first" actually mean aside from a clever marketing slogan? Who is the BI in BI Lahey Health? Interest in innovation is not the same as supporting the process of innovation.

review_title: Great place to learn; not great pay practices
pros: Education opportunitites are great here, employees are treated well generally with the exception of specific floor managers from time to time like any place. The hospital genuinely promotes an environment of transparency, accountability and respect. I honestly learn something new here each week, the patient care is excellent and there is a sense of professionalism everywhere.
cons: the pay rate is not great for Boston, shift diffs are weak. Also not punching in and out gouges employees who are clearly not leaving at the exact end of their scheduled hours, employees are only paid for scheduled hours (8 or 12 hrs) if you stay late to finish an admission so as not to dump it on the next shift-that's on your own time. I really miss the union perks like lunch or dinner breaks! And parking rates only discounted after 9P stinks- also shuttle to T stops ends at 830P

review_title: Overworked and Underpaid but Great Team Enviornment
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: The team of CRAs/CRCs is amazing. I have met some great friends here; they are extremely hard working, despite the work environment. The doctors who work on the trials can be difficult to work with sometimes, but many of them are willing to be mentors and provide a great resource for individuals who want to get the most out of this job.
cons:
Work expected of you is not equal to pay. As a CRC or CRA, you are expected to do far more than your job description and you are not adequately compensated for it. I have been told on numerous occasions that I am significantly underpaid given my workload. 

Management also needs to be overhauled. There is a culture of bad management and no openness to fixing the problem. People get promoted from within (which is good) but do not get adequate managerial training and often do not seem to be candidates with the right personality to be successful managers.

pros: Upper management are very personable.  They will smile and speak.  Though it's a large organization, you do not just feel like a number here.  They also have many multicultural celebrations as well as Employee appreciation events throughout the year.
cons: The price of parking is absolutely ridiculous and it continues to rise each fiscal year.  I understand the medical center is in a congested location but I honestly think they could help us out some with the parking rates!  If you're in an administrative/clerical position, be prepared to not get paid your worth.  I have 20 years of experience and I'm being paid what someone fresh out of college would get paid.

pros: The employee healthcare package is really good.  I felt it really was really a lot especially if you got your care there are the hospital.
cons: I do not feel they invest in their employees.  Turn over is so great.  People go for training and leave after a year or two.  They see older people getting work related injuries and treated very poorly.  Only the very very strong survive there.  If you are ever hurt....consider yourself out of luck. In my particular department people would ask for a vacation (even just 1 day, like for wedding or something) up to 2 years in advance and got denied.  People have left due to bad life / work balance.  Other departments may not be so bad.

review_title: BIDMC is a great place to work if you can get in the door and stay there.
pros:
The nurse manager was a great manager.  She was very attentive to her nurses and always maintained a presence on the floor.
The staff was very friendly.
cons: When I started working there I was a student working as a nursing assistant.  I graduated in 2009 and the hospital was in a hiring freeze because of the economy.  Therefore, upon graduation I had no job offer.  I was unable to continue working there because after I earned my RN license you are not allowed to work below your license. I was dissatisfied with BIDMC's lack of support towards my career.  Typically they hire their new grads, but in this case they were not able to and despite the fact that they are now accepting new grads and I apply to every position I still don't hear from them.

pros: BIDMC has great opportunities for recent graduates who would like to ease into their first "real" job. Training was very thorough and there were a lot of other young people with whom I could relate which made the day to day bearable.
cons: There is little to no growth opportunity. This is truly a first job where you should learn as much as possible as quickly as possible so that you can leave. The salary is FAR from competitive and the upper management does not seem interested in helping you learn and grow outside of your specific role. Educational research should be about learning, and without this I see no reason to not take an industry job where you will get paid double, have more opportunity for growth, and maybe even learn more.

review_title: It was okay as a job that would get me the experience I needed to move on to a better job.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: While the benefits were mediocre, there were some nice perks (like Red Sox tickets, etc.) that made up for some of the other downfalls. Also, it was easy to take time off when I needed to and paid time off hours accrued very quickly.
cons: The compensation is lower than what you would find at other comparable institutions and while we were constantly working overtime, the system made it nearly impossible to be paid for those extra hours. There is very little room to grow in the company and promotions are pretty much only based on the number of years that you have worked, not how qualified you are for the position.

job_title: Regulatory Affairs Specialist in Boston, MA
pros: The environment of the office is casual and everyone is helpful and works together. $5 Red Sox tickets are a big perk.
cons: There is disconnect in higher management. They do not understand day-to-day workings of the office and do not allow the managers to manage. This creates a lot of frustration for all employees. Senior management focuses on numbers, but doesn't account for the man power needed to achieve the desired accrual goals. Therefore, the base level employees are overworked for extremely low pay and without any accolades or acknowledgment of their work. At one point Clinical Research Assistants were paid below minimum wage for 6 months before the mistake was caught.

review_title: Growth by attrition, stay away if you want a competitive salary/growth opportunities
job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros:
Impactful work that really makes a difference in the lives of patients, regardless of your job description or role. Every role provides a useful service to the betterment of sick patients, which is both ambitious and admirable.
Large number of physicians seem to buy into the core BIDMC philosophy of a patient-first environment.
Opportunity for growth if you're proactive (stems mainly from covering  vacancies from rampant employee attrition)
cons:
Management at the clinical administrative level is truly abysmal. Lack of communication often leaves employees in the dark. This problem is is no way  isolated to one Division.
No pipeline for top admin performers at the clinical level, so attrition is out of control. Staff of 11 had 10 resignations in 14 months. Does this sound normal?
Low compensation compared to the industry average in Boston (including nearby medical centers).

review_title: Good learning experience but not much room for growth
pros: Great life learning experience.  BIDMC as a whole, and as a patient provider, is great (my own doctor was located there for years).  My review is about my employment experience.
cons:
Salary is low, even when compared to comparable positions in nearby hospitals.  Not much room for growth.
I worked at an ARO within the hospital, the tried to act as its own entity, but was bound by BIDMC rules. Because there was a limited budget, we relied heavily on volunteer international fellows seeking US medical residency, so turnover was high and frequent. Even staff turnover was high and frequent. Environment at work was always tense and unnecessarily frantic and stressful.  Management fostered an environment that pitted employees against fellows rather than a truly collaborative, learning environment.  There was absolutely no work-life balance, and when you took time off, you were still expected to respond to emails/texts/calls immediately (even if you are at a relative's funeral).

review_title: Lots of great things to say BUT...
pros:
- Health insurance is affordable and offers great coverage, especially if you are seen by a BIDMC physician.
- A+ culture/values 
- Upper management is committed to doing a regular employee satisfaction survey and a few minor issues have been addressed
cons:
- Failure to follow through on promises made to employees: I was promised a promotion for 5 months before it became official, only to have my raise cut to 1/4 of the promised amount! I would have quit on the spot if my husband hadn't just lost his job. 
- Failure to get rid of bad employees
-Extremely high turnover. My immediate group of 5 people is new within the last 6 months. I am the only one who has stayed.
- Staff in my department are extremely overworked
- Lack of teamwork between departments
-Management is afraid of the physicians and won't discuss sensitive topics like moving offices etc

review_title: Trading unpaid overtime for a wealth of strictly pre-PhD experience.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: Longwood Medical Area educational opportunities, networking within and without highly influential institutions, close work with leaders of your field, access to cutting-edge academia and clinical practices
cons: Heavy social pressure from above to do much more than what you're paid for and at times, what's even on the books, unpaid overtime considered the norm in research, old boy's club makes it harder to advance as a young woman in some areas, some outdated and disproven clinical philosophies grandfathered in along with their practitioners (although much less so than in other institutions)

review_title: Use to be a good place to work
pros:
- A big name on your CV
- Relaxed Environment
cons:
- No respect for none medical staff- Especially if you are not a doctor they  are rude and treat you like a dumb person
- Only RNs can climb the career ladder. For every managerial position, you have to be a RN. If you are not you'll not get anywhere. 
- Every year they cut more benefits. Such as free overnight parking, Tuition reimbursement program, etc . There used to be a daycare center on campus years ago, but now there is nothing, not even a subsided offsite daycare. All insurances reimburse a portion of your gym membership. But here you either have to exercise at the tiny basement gym or you'll get nothing! 
- For none clinical workers there is absolutely no training, learning opportunity provided.  They will not send you to a single conference or training. That is just for MDs with their fancy discretionary accounts.

pros: The benefits they offer could be good if you have time off to use them.
cons: Don't work for APG they are cheap and are only out for the dollar! I thought when I was getting hired that I would be working for BI but found out I was going to be working with the red heading step child company APG ( Affiliated Partners Group ). They do not care about much other then making sure they get paid even if they put ogres to manage their practices. They have a few awesome managers but they are definitely the minority. They understaff to save a buck and over work employees always asking to come in early or stay late. No room for growth either. If you want a miserable work life then APG is for you.

review_title: Working in the labs at BIDMC is great for personal/intellectual development, but don't go there for the money.
pros: I get to do work that is potentially really important, and that could lead to breakthroughs in medical science.  I am given lots of responsibility, which is important for learning how to manage projects and how to get things done.
cons: The area outside our lab is pretty bad; the bathrooms are disgusting, and sometimes there's weird liquids on the floor, which I assume come from the garbage that is passed near our lab every day on the way to the dumpster.  The lab space itself is small; nobody has enough room for their stuff.  And the pay is crap for the amount of work we have to do.

job_title: Client Program Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Linearly - great employees and colleagues.
cons: Management tolerates clinician bullying of admins.   Double standard for clinicians and admins; some docs and nurses engage in inappropriate comments or failure to bill and are still there years later.  Admins make errors and are dismissed immediately.

job_title: Research Assistant III in Boston, MA
pros: Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center has many research opportunities for young graduates to start off their careers.  Young graduates can use these opportunities to help them gain experience for their future endeavors.
cons: Since the research departments are affiliated with Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, the % increase in raises and rate of promotion follows hospital rules even though it's essentially independent of the hospital.

pros: Leadership ladder program for nurses; opportunities for moving up. Supportive nursing management. Different units are open to testing new ways of doing things; a spirit of innovation and improvement. Physicians, in general, have good working relationships with nurses, generally speaking. Good interpreter services. Good benefits. I was a patient here as well and felt well taken care of.
cons: Wish there were more people of color in leadership and nursing positions.  My manager boasted of such a "diverse" team, but 2 out of 14 did not seem so outstanding, especially considering how many of our patients were people of color and people from other countries. Culturally speaking, the staff and patients don't resemble each other. However staff generally did provide culturally sensitive care.

review_title: Great place to work up till the last 1-2 years
pros: Great clinicians and staff who care deeply about the patients they serve and who work extremely hard despite cutbacks on staffing, supplies and equipment
cons: (New) Senior team disengaged from front line issues; CEO externally focused, delegated all decisions to COO who is culturally insensitive to the needs of staff. Seems there is a lot of senior management strife which is new and has appeared in the last year or so

review_title: Nice place to work, but not much room for growth
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Harvard Affiliate, decent cafeteria, convenient location
cons:
HR controls salaries even in grant-funded positions, little-to-no morale-building activities (look for a new/tech company for any fun employer activities), very old-age dynamic. Making taking a "selfie" with one of the Red Sox World Series rings an event is laughable.

Buildings are older and benefits aren't spectacular. Administrative structure creates unnecessary obstacles for research teams, making you question whether research and innovation are a value or just the bottom line.

There is no structure for advancement in positions or salaries. If you want to move up or find new challenges, you're going to have to apply for a new position either in another department or elsewhere.

pros: I was at Beth Israel as an intern and now as an employee. I've experienced a wonderfully collaborative culture, a commitment to employee growth and education, and a place where it feels safe to ask questions and receive support. It's very supportive, challenging, and interesting! Great people.
cons: As with any hospital, collaboration can vary floor to floor. Some areas of the hospital feel better to me than others. Also, I'd like to see a greater commitment to having POC in upper level positions and in the social work department.

pros: The Harvard medical research and clinical network is immense and having a Harvard e-mail can open a lot of doors.  Good insurance, $5 red sox tickets.  Very multinational and ambitious collaborators.
cons:
Expensive to live near, expensive to park near.  Commutes can be long and Boston drivers are tense.  Environment can be demanding which produces an occasionally nasty/bitter co-worker.
  Research space in my group was tight and unorganized, which led to unnecessary tension exacerbated by a particularly nasty administrator

pros: Part of a team that is doing something great for research
cons: Unappreciated by most staff, overworked and underpaid, given urgent work last minute (esp grant and manuscript submissions) on regular basis despite repeat deadline reminders to PIs

pros: Great place to work - challenged but rewarding culture; good benefits and pay; role allows for a great work life balance; potential merger could lead to awesome career growth. There are several long term employees here that show the great longevity the hospital can provide. Highly recommend!
cons: Parking/commuting can expensive in the area; however this is subsidized by the hospital to help alleviate these costs. Some areas of the hospital need improvement from a facilities standpoint; however this has been an area of focus and improve mrs have been made.

review_title: BIDMC is a feel-good place to work, but compensation could be better.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: The sense of community is great. I really appreciate their efforts to hire from within and provide free job training and citizenship counseling to their employees. Everyone seems cheerful and people say hello in the hallways. These things are what keep me wanting to work at BIDMC.
cons: Research seems to provide very little career advancement opportunities, and it seems like we are underpaid compared to neighboring institutions. Benefits could be improved. I like that sick time, vacation, and holidays are all rolled into one pot of earned time, but I know that this can be tough for some people.

review_title: Stable enough opportunities but difficult to make a career.
pros: The Medical Center puts out a real effort to make original ideas and present itself as a patient centered environment. Healthcare benefits and discounts on T passes are nice add ons. Very accesible by public transportation.
cons: Constant communication issues. Frequent hiring of people who do not possess enough knowledge about healthcare administration. No ladder apparent to further your career. Pay is below normal. Frequent new initiatives that seem to come from nowhere with little or no imput from the practices affected. Really outdated computer technology.

review_title: BIDMC is a great work environment and is full of loyal veteran employees
pros: BIDMC has a strong sense of community. The new COO definitely cares about what employees think and wants to implement the reasonable changes that are being requested. Also, the hospital offers great insurance and decent benefits.
cons: the hierarchal structure is a bit intimidating. sometimes you feel like you can't say hello to senior management. also, because it is a nonprofit, the salaries are a bit low. i think it would boost employee morale if salaries were raised by a certain percentage

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Boston, MA
pros: They care about patients and have been able to demonstrate some agile leadership in the midst of COVID.
cons: I am new but I sense there are many sub-cultures at the departmental level. I don't know what the organizational culture is yet. While the organization seems progressive and has taken a few actions to address institutional racism which is pervasive in every Harvard affiliated hospital - I am not optimistic these actions will be sufficient to fundamentally shift the culture. Diversity at the leadership level is almost non-existent and I don't see what the organization is doing to address this other than provide some optional resources to their employees. There are no accountability measures that I am aware of.

pros: At times fulfilling but things rarely go the way they should. No real learning curve. Processes are pretty dated so no need to be a superstar with computers.
cons: Difficult to get Drs. engaged in education. Too often the position seems like just non-stop harassing of physicians via email. Doesn't pay enough for how demanding the job is. Budgets are a constant concern, so much so that it is over-scrutinized when ordering things like Kleenex. Facilities are old and outdated. Things are constantly breaking like computers, heat/AC, etc. Little to no career growth available.

review_title: I have been an RN here for the last 3 years! I have always been treated as part of a team
pros: Teamwork. I have always been supported in this environment. From my coworkers on the floor to my managers I’ve been given the upmost support and moving towards my career goals and meeting them.
cons: Childcare benefits for employees is nearly nonexistent. I do not have children myself but as an advocate to change the future of the workplace benefits. I would hope to see a change in the future that would benefit each employee who works in a position of long hours from 7 to 7 in meeting the demands for childcare for these long hours.

review_title: Love Working Here! Would Love for the Higher Ups to Pay Attention...
pros: The people I work with are fantastic! Everyone from environmental services to the nurse managers are wonderful. SO much room for career advancement with the right education! They really like giving people the opportunity to grow and attain better jobs.
cons: Staff members have a lot of productive ideas that the higher ups just don't listen to. While there are many great things, there's also a lot of room for improvement. They either don't hear us or don't listen.

review_title: Caring culture, bad HR paperwork and processes
pros: Genuinely cared about staff welfare - fitness programs, lots of campaigns to raise awareness of stress and other issues, etc. Also some great discounts with partners - from fitness centers to insurance.
cons: Hated the paperwork and arbitrary HR processes, which were mostly all manual and had to be physically delivered / got lost. Really long process and had to repeat many things. Also quite unpleasant ladies with bad attitude working in HR.

pros: Small, community hospital.  People have worked here forever…..employs older workers (45+)
cons: Can be "clicky" since so many employees have been there forever.  Benefits are subpar for a hospital.  There are other non city hospitals that have better benefits.  Pay is good, but benefits are costly, so any salary bump goes back into the benefit plan.

review_title: Lot of nice people, good exposure to a hospital setting for pre-meds
pros: great benefits, flexible work schedule.
cons: at least for recent med school aspiring college grads who are seeking entry level coordinator, assistant positions: a lot of the work is monotonous.

job_title: Human Resources Associate in Boston, MA
pros: A great place to get on your feet with your career post-college. Plenty of opportunities throughout the medical center and its affiliates.
cons: Growth depends on what department you're in. If there's no clear path you're expected to move laterally to a different department, despite years of experience.

pros: Large cubicles. Well-known employer.
cons: Cattiest atmosphere that I have ever worked in, hands down.  Staff spends most of their time secretly complaining to management about other workers, trying (and succeeding) to get someone fired for extraordinarily petty reasons, usually they have no reason at all for their complaints.  For example, someone used the wrong copy machine to make a copy, unaware that they were only allowed to use one certain copier.  Resulted in a complaint that went all the way to the director.  Person got fired.  Another one got fired because work piled up on her desk while she was not in the office for a couple of days.  Extremely stupid complaints; severe overreactions.

job_title: Research Assistant III in Boston, MA
pros: The research and clinical community collaborate pretty well.  There are lots of perks; discounted red sox and movie tickets to name two.  People seem very friendly generally.
cons: As an employee in research, one gets the impression that research support is not a primary concern.  Some aspects of the research infrastructure can be troublesome to navigate (IT in particular).

job_title: Spanish Medical Interpreter in Boston, MA
pros: Warm, friendly staff throughout the hospital
cons: Earned Time (time off) lumps sick time and vacation time all together and it is a very stressful system. If you get sick, you don't want to stay home because you lose vacation time, and holidays are not "free" as they are at other places, but they deduct hours from your Earned Time so you learn to resent holidays.

pros: Working at BIDMC was a great opportunity. As a BIDMC employee, you're surrounded by healthcare professionals who are passionate about providing the highest quality of care to the community and beyond. Employees in non-medical roles match that passion about raising the brand and reputation of the medical center. In my experience, everyone at BIDMC works tirelessly but also puts an emphasis on having a healthy work-life balance. I learned so much from my colleagues and am grateful for the opportunity to have worked there.
cons: Some of the buildings are outdated and hard to navigate.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: Coworkers make bad days bearable. Most of the management express compassion.  Great location.  There are many challenges, and you are constantly learning.
cons: Not much of a work life balance, pay isn't enough for the amount/complication of work, there are very few incentives to keep up employee moral.

review_title: Has become an uncomfortable place to work
pros: Great clinicians who are dedicated to their patients
cons: Senior management changes has resulted in an aloof, exclusive inner circle with poor communication. Most staff are anxious and morale has tanked

pros: Amazing research is being done at this place. Some of the smartest people in the world work here. Busy but still a good hospital.
cons: Terrible salaries. It's to be expected when working for a non-profit organization, but the CEO salaries are still going up.

pros: Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center offers competitive pay and some nice perks($5 Red Sox tickets.) I have never had any bad experiences with management or other staff.
cons: Human Resources at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center can be a little hard to deal with. I had a very hard time getting in contact with them when getting hired. The labs could use some updating.

review_title: Great work environment but needs higher pay
job_title: Critical Care RN in Boston, MA
pros: The culture is great. Nurses and physicians work well together. Great support from coworkers and fellow nurses.  I learn a lot from the nurses and MDs.
cons: Parking is very expensive in Boston. The salary for nurses is not enough. There should be better compensation for nurses. Also the ratio of patients to nurses is too high in the ICU. Most patients are doubled.

pros:
good benefits
good experience but not for long term employment
good place to use as a stepping stone for another job (Harvard looks good on resume)
cons:
Low pay
Expected to work overtime, but since they put you on salary you won't get paid for it
Very poor management in the Research and Academics department
The amount of work often exceeds the 40 hour/week salary

review_title: A good company to work for. Pay scale quite low even for an academic institution
pros:
Amazing science and discovery. A very prestigious institution as a part of Harvard Medical School. You get to work with well known scientist on some of the most important aspects of medical care.
Decent benefits.
cons: Low salary in a very expensive place to live.

pros:
Most colleagues are fantastic to work with and always willing to help
Great about personal time as needed.
Will give you opportunities to grow and learn by doing
cons:
No upward movement (no matter what they tell )
Lack of respect in action, very fake with empty Thank you's
Will continue to add work without compensation making you think you're headed toward a potential higher position

job_title: Research Assistant III in Boston, MA
pros:
Excellent opportunitites to gain research lab experience
Very flexible hours
Pleasant work enviornment
cons:
As a research assistant there is very little opportunity for advancement, the only higher positions are Post-docs and staff scientists, both of which requiire PhDs.  
As an academic lab the salaries are small with little room for increase - position and salary dependent on PI's grants.

review_title: A second family focused on patient care
pros: For a large institution, BIDMC has a very family-like feel.  The employee benefits and self-improvement programs highlight the center's appreciation of its employees.  In turn, employees are dedicated to working hard, taking good care of patients.  BIDMC is one of the nation's largest research centers and excels in medical advances.
cons: The only con is logistical in nature - lack of parking.  Par for the course in a small area of 5 large medical centers.

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: Safe job if you willing to kiss people  S
cons:
They are becoming very opportunistic, by hiring less people and make you work way more and no payment increase.
Managers very arrogant, ready to give you warning for anything.
Very tough to get day off in case you need it .

job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: BIDMC provides a good research community with access to many different research resources. Great co-workers too, but that will largely depend on who ends up being your manager.
cons: The pay is low, but not significantly lower than other academic medical research jobs in the area. There is not a lot of opportunity for career advancement.

review_title: Will risk Patient Safety to cut costs
pros: No pros other then the minimal paycheck
cons:
Low Pay, Expensive Health Insurance, Expensive parking. Many areas/practices are safety issues for employees. 
No system in place for CONFIDENTIAL grievances.

review_title: Great experience & stepping stone to higher ed
pros:
Work with highly motivated recent grads
Supportive multidisciplinary team environment
Many staff value your development
cons:
Some disconnect between faculty and clinical technicians/research assistants
Hierarchical nature of medicine leads to not feeling very respected at work from some staff
Not much supervision (though available if you ask and take initiative)

pros: Pay: I was given more than I askedfor, and the benefits are good.
cons: Low morale, stressful work environment

pros:
Flexible hours
People are really nice 
Decent benefits and pay
Proud work
Nice environment
Great location with proximity to the T (Orange and Green)
cons: There is a very public controversy with its CEO that has caused stress among the employees, specially the faculty, but overall leadership has done a great job.

review_title: I have been associated with the Medical Center off and on for 20 years.
pros:
High quality of professional staff.
Pride in the good care given patients.
Management in my professional department is excellent.
cons:
Lack of leadership in the specific clinic in which I work.
Poor communication among management staff in the clinic.
Not as friendly and team oriented as I like.

review_title: Do Not Work for IT Dept at BIDMC
job_title: IS Support Tech in Boston, MA
pros: Pro-the day you leave BIDMC
cons: Desktop Support (field service), Helpdesk and Inventory control are two IS groups that are micro managed and poorly supported. These areas are nothing but "ticket mills" withg the calls piling up with no help in site. The pay is very low in contrast to other area Hospitals. Management in these areas "bully" their employees.

review_title: More of a senior or less patient service representative
job_title: Administrative Practice Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: You meet a lot of great people to network with. It serves more of a stepping stone in a career.
cons: Non competitive pay. There is no room for raises, only a really low annual raise that doesn't help much. People feel stagnant.

review_title: Good People But Slow To Adapt To Changing Healthcare Landscape
job_title: Heart Monitoring Technician in Boston, MA
pros: It's an incredible learning experience. You can take what you learn in this position to any sort of position whether or not you choose to stay in healthcare.
cons: Pay is usually not great. When I was there people were complaining that the hospital was rapidly expanding and they weren't getting paid enough. Office politics may be present.

review_title: great opportunity for research at your own pace
job_title: Research Fellow/Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: your PI will always be available to speak and help you out. your coworkers are extremely knowledgable and will help you through most of the roadblocks that you may hit in research
cons: some complications with getting access to specific parts of the building without hours of shuffling through people, low salary even for research

pros: Great clinical care despite dearth of resources and equipment.
cons: Does anyone trust management? Leadership strife is evident and worries many of us.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Boston, MA
pros: Great coworkers.  Very interesting position as an ambulatory pharmacy technician.  Gained a lot of experience while working at Health Care Associates.
cons: Poor and disfunction management at Health Care Associates.  Management will listen to your concerns, but does not make promised changes.  When changes occur, they take so long that more changes are needed because what was changed is no longer relevant.

pros: Salary was great, and caring for patients is always rewarding
cons: Toxic staff/employees/department, micro-management, lack of support from directors, and had to wear a pager, Physicians were disrespectful

pros: Location is easily accessible by public transportation.  Friendly atmosphere.  Lots of options for food places during lunch.  Staff is freat, awesome teamwork environment.  Great oportunity for career advancement after 6 months of employment.
cons: Unless you ask how are you doing on your current role, you do not get any feedback until your 1 yr review.

pros: great co-workers. great relationship between RN and MDs and other teams. communication improvement is a focus of the hospital.
cons: overworked managers and floor staff. consistently unsafe staffing at night. a lot of things are still on paper.

review_title: Love my lab, actual Company forgets about research
pros:
Partnership with Harvard Med
Access to research journals
Good insurance
Good location
cons:
I think BIDMC frequently forgets that they have a research department - I received a 3 year anniversary "card" that was a generic pamphlet written with medical staff in mind, and the orientation for new workers was entirely geared towards patient-facing employees.
The pay is not great; my PI would love to pay me more but HR flatly refused.

review_title: It's a great working environment but...
pros: Busy med/surg floor,so learned a great deal. My co workers appreciated my work ethic,great team.
cons: Pay.  If you're not a nurse,you're definitely not valued by management. It's not fair wage for the work I do. Raises do not reflect real life. I work full time and still needed OT.

pros: Job is easy, pay is good, and flexibility with shifts is excellent. Most people who work there are very nice.
cons: Management is hands off, give their work to the lower employees. Don't know their employees value and easily get involved in employee drama. No HR in dept.

review_title: Be wary of this place or you will find yourself stuck in a rut and miserable in a thankless job
pros: my team of great staff members kept me sane while I was there, the recurring patients with whom I built a strong repore, i'm no longer there anymore
cons: poor salary, subpar benefits, management is incompetent and unwilling to actively support staff members, no growth or upward mobility, favoritism, lack of appreciation for work product

review_title: Great job working with a amazing team of people
job_title: Emergency Room Tech in Needham, MA
pros: Fairly busy emergency room. Everyone is very team oriented. Really enjoy working in this department.
cons: As with any ER job the hours are not always the best. Emergency rooms are open 24/7 365 days a year so chances are you are going to be stuck working some nights/weekends/holidays. This can put a strain on your family life. The pay is also not so great.

pros: They care about their employees and keep them updated on things are going on at all the Beth Israel sites.  Quality of care to patients is a top priority.
cons: The office's are so busy that there is no time to train people on what they need to do or know.

pros: It is a good atmosphere for learning a lot from graduate student, post-docs and other lab technicians who have been there longer. It is also a great job to gain experience in the field before figuring out your eventual career path, either medical school or graduate school etc.
cons: HR is not always very organized or quick to respond to problems that may happen in the research sector of the hospital.

pros: It's all about patients and staff really believe in this. Great care and reputation in the Boston Longwood area
cons: The hospital network is experiencing growth, but staff can't keep up. Long hours, hard work and can be stressful.

pros: Very good medical/clinical experience for applying to medical school. The physicians were mostly friendly and helpful.
cons: Almost unlivable salary for the Boston area, and much lower tuition reimbursement than surrounding hospitals. Usually ended up working more hours than you get paid for.

job_title: Instructor/Staff Ph D in Boston, MA
pros: Intellectual freedom. Some flexibility to the hours you may work. Proximity (but almost total separateness from) Harvard Medical School (HMS).
cons: Management will use your ideas without contributing to their development. Pay rises are hard to come by. Supervision is lax and mentorship is non-existent unless you hold an MD.

review_title: My experience at BIDMC has been eye opening!
job_title: Community Resource Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Diverse workplace and clientele, great location, great team work, ability to use my full skill set, great patient care, flexibility
cons: Not much room for growth, upper management not fully aware of the day to day details of the job, a lot of wasted time in meetings, not enough pay, turn over rate very high,

review_title: Just ok, not the best research environment.
job_title: Senior Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Convenient location and Earn Time system allows to accumulate time off quite quickly.
cons: Benefits and salary are worse than other nearby hospitals affiliated with HMS. Some of the core facilities are very inefficient and expensive.

pros: To build up sense of success on health improvement on combination of both medicines(Western and Chinese), and then figure out the real natural relationship between Human's health and environment of our world.
cons: share others with personal enjoyable life to review that the  response to every things  in life must be positive.

pros: Challenging work, generally a very positive working environment
cons: Trying to get paid at market rates is a disappointing process, even when supported by senior management.  HR has their marching orders, and they know how to march.

pros: Friendly and flexible work environment. There is definitely a sense of community. Health insurance and other benefits are also good
cons: Dealing with HR and Finance divisions not always the best. Took me 2 months to get a paycheck once

review_title: Draining place to work. But it depends on Department.
job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Boston, MA

pros: Nice small community hospital. Love my co-workers and patients. It is a nice training hospital for those of you who are new to the healthcare field.
cons: No opportunity for advancement. Unfair practices when seeking other employment opportunities within hospital. Low compensation. No management. No communication.

pros:
- Amazing program director - very understanding of different individual goals with career/family/hobbies and works to create a schedule to fit it

cons:
- high volume of chronic-pain patients that BIDMC seems to attract
- minimal admin support for fax/requesting records; uploading/acquiring OSH radiology studies

review_title: It's place which hones your professional skills.
job_title: Flow Cytometry Assistant in Boston, MA

cons: As a teaching hospital of Havard Medical School, sometimes you get annoyed by unprofessional behavior of the trainees.

review_title: Bad experience, but it likely depends on the department / research group

- Many young people in my study group
- Stable job security
cons:
- Clear hierarchy based upon medical degree status
- Pay is below that of other hospitals in the area
- Unprofessional management in some departments
- Few vacation days -- must use vacation days for sick days which encourages employees to go to work sick

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA

cons: The hospital setting for research can be a little frustrating.  Mostly because many seemingly benign aspects of research still require hospital staff to also monitor.

pros: Benefits vary based on department, but our department pays for parking.  You don't get much free food like during residency.  Health care costs are reasonable. Nice neighborhoods close to the hospital where you can live so you can walk to work.   Great clinical training and research opportunities.
cons: Not too much to say, I'm very happy with fellowship here.

pros: nice family/work balance, nice people, nice work environment, good benefits,
cons:
poor training, 3% annual increases across the board leaves give no incentive to excel,
a lot of gossiping amongst the directors, if your good at your job you are stuck there and not many insecure directors, offered growth opportunities, a lot of favoritism,

pros: Access to experienced people who are willing to share their time.
cons: The benefits, location, facilities and location (yes, I meant to repeat that)

pros: The culture of the work environment at BIDMC is like no other I've known in the healthcare industry.
cons: The different units and departments are not equally advanced in supporting a healthy work environment. I worked in nursing administration and found the executives there to be strong advocates of care for all levels of staff.

pros: People historically are very special, especially those who have been there for 10+ years.  Good benefits.  Typical pay for hospital environment.
cons: They are in cross hairs of so many changes to healthcare.  It is a bit bumpy right now.  Hopefully will return to the very nice place to work that it always was.

job_title: Administrative Operations Manager in Boston, MA
pros: some of the employees are the nicest you will ever meet and great people to know
cons: there are managers and resource who do not support your success and there is no work life balance

review_title: good job for starting out in medical profession
pros: good environment, benefits and salary. things that are good are worth being there for, I have enjoyed my overall experience at beth israel deaconess medical center
cons: culture can be a bit stressful sometimes. management is tough but recognizes accomplishments and achievements of their employees. i think that it can be way too uptight sometimes

pros: Good employer relationships and state of the art IT processing applications. Advancement oppertunities and oncall pay with overtime available as well.
cons:
Benifits could be better as well as anual pay raise. 
Trainning classes could be better and offered when available to staff.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Boston, MA

review_title: not the greatest-weakest support for academic science among the Longwood Medical area hospitals

review_title: A professional, respectful atmosphere but no time for career development

pros: Great working environment, people who work there are nice, and very competitve.

pros: part of the Harvard Medical School network, half-off MBTA pass, CLS research building has nice research benches.

pros: The hospital itself is renowned for a reason - the doctors are great!

pros: Pretty good health benefits and the $5 tickets aren't bad

pros: I have worked as an RN full time, part tome and per diem over the last 30 years on the same unit. My work is dynamic, busy and fulfilling. Administration is supportive and fair.

pros: Having worked at BIDMC for over 25 years ,it is a Harvard teaching hospital with constant educational growth,  up to date equipment and monitoring systems, and good benefits.

pros: The physicians and other providers are usually willing to teach if you are young and looking for direction in the health care field.

Stable environment. Nice area close to other teaching hospitals , shops, and food court.

pros: Learned healthcare enjoyed at first, nightmare of a medical facility

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Boston, MA

review_title: Salary is not the reason people stay

review_title: Perfect Place for Entry Level Job in Research

review_title: Proud to say I work at  BIDMC

review_title: Good hospital to work with especially in the Needham location

review_title: good place to work if you don't mind pay
